case_info.docket_number: Case No. CV11-0724 (Central District of California)

company.name: Playdom, Inc.
company.address: Los Angeles, California and other U.S. cities
company.business_description: Playdom, a subsidiary of Disney Enterprises, Inc., operates online virtual worlds and games. The company is the successor to Acclaim Games, Inc., and operates multiple online gaming platforms including 2 Moons, 9 Dragons, Age of Lore, Bots, Dance Online, Knight's Blood, and other online games and virtual worlds.

case_info.legal_authority: Sections 1303(c) and 1306(d) of the Children's Online Privacy Protection Act of 1998 (COPPA), 15 U.S.C. §§ 6501-6506, 6502(c) and 6505(d), and Sections 5(a)(1), 5(m)(1)(A), 13(b), and 16(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act (FTC Act), 15 U.S.C. §§ 41-58, 45(a)(1), 45(m)(1)(A), 53(b), and 56(a)

complaint.factual_background: Between 2006 and 2010, Defendants Playdom, Inc. (successor to Acclaim Games, Inc.) and its CEO Howard Marks operated approximately twenty online virtual worlds that collected personal information from children under age 13 without obtaining verifiable parental consent. Although Defendants' registration flow identified users under 13 and prompted entry of a parent's email address, children were immediately granted full access to the games and their personal profiles upon registration—before any parental consent was confirmed. Defendants' privacy policy falsely stated that children would be prohibited from disclosing personal information such as real names, addresses, and contact details, yet in practice Defendants allowed children to publicly post such information through profile pages and community forums. In approximately 1,224,000 instances, Defendants collected, used, and/or disclosed children's personal information in violation of the Children's Online Privacy Protection Rule.

representations_made.description: Defendants represented in their privacy policy that when a child under 13 signs up, they would not collect the child's email address without parental permission, would not collect anything beyond the listed items, and would require that children not disclose personal contact information when posting or chatting online.
representations_made.quoted_text: 1 3. When a child under 13 years of age signs up we not 2 [s ic] collect the Email address without the permission of 3 the Parent or Legal Guardian and we will collect the 4 other items listed above. We do not collect anything 5 else. If a child under 13 years of age wants to post 6 information on our website or chat with other players, we 7 will require that they do not disclose any personal 8 information such as the real name, address, phone 9 number and anything that can be used to contact the 10 child.

representations_made.description: Through the same privacy policy statements, Defendants represented expressly or by implication that they would prohibit children from posting personal information online, including information that could be used to contact such children.
representations_made.quoted_text: 6 28. Through the statements made in the privacy policy referenced in 7 Paragraph 19 above, Defendants represented, expressly or by implication, that they 8 would prohibit children from posting personal information online, including 9 information that could be used to contact such children.

counts.title: Violations of the Children's Online Privacy Protection Rule
counts.representation: Defendants operated websites and online services through which they collected, with actual knowledge, personal information from children under age 13, including through at least one site (Pony Stars) directed to children.
counts.fact: Defendants failed to: (a) provide sufficient notice on their websites of what information they collected from children, how it was used, and their disclosure practices (violating 16 C.F.R. § 312.4(b)); (b) provide direct notice to parents of their information collection, use, and disclosure practices (violating 16 C.F.R. § 312.4(c)); and (c) obtain verifiable parental consent before any collection, use, or disclosure of personal information from children (violating 16 C.F.R. § 312.5(a)(1)).
counts.conclusion: Therefore, Defendants have violated the Children's Online Privacy Protection Rule, 16 C.F.R. Part 312.

counts.title: Misrepresentation in Violation of Section 5 of the FTC Act
counts.representation: Through statements in their privacy policy, Defendants represented, expressly or by implication, that they would prohibit children from posting personal information online, including information that could be used to contact such children.
counts.fact: In truth and in fact, Defendants permitted children to disclose their personal information online through personal profile pages and community forums.
counts.conclusion: Therefore, the representation set forth in Paragraph 28 was false and misleading, and constitutes a deceptive act or practice in violation of Section 5(a) of the FTC Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a).
